III. INVESTIGATION
1

Rule Code Eligibility requirements
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12504
Section (2) All the following must be in the case record before a youth is
Description placed in independent living:
(c) That the youth's social service worker has personally observed
and determined that the living situation is safe, and that the youth
has a bed and has access to cooking and bathing facilities.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A calls Youth B slurs. On 02/18/24, Youth A threatened to
kill Youth B, and Youth A pushed Youth B and tried to fight Youth
B. There were no staff present. There is no on call number for
residents to call. It was reported there was a syringe needle sitting
in the bathtub from a previous resident. The syringe continues to
sit in the bathtub. The bathtub is not working and is filled with
clothes and other items. There is mold in the showers.
Investigation Interviews:
I interviewed Complainant 1 by telephone on 2/20/2024.
Complainant did not have anything additional to add about these
allegations.
I interviewed House Supervisor 1 onsite with State Worker 1 on
2/21/2024. House Supervisor 1 stated the program currently has
3 participants, Youth A, Youth B, and Complainant 1. House
Supervisor 1 described Youth A as not getting along well with
Youth B, but there have not been any physical
confrontations/conflicts between Youth A and Youth B. House
Supervisor 1 reported Youth B as being a participant in the
program for approximately 18 months and doing well in the
program. House Supervisor 1 stated Complainant 1 and Youth B
as doing well in the program. House Supervisor 1 stated
Complainant 1 does not spend a lot of time at the residence and
typically will only check in a few times during the week and then
leave. Contact information was posted on the refrigerator for
residents to contact staff as needed when staff was not required to
be onsite. House Supervisor 1 reported staff is required to be
onsite 16 hours a day per contract. House Supervisor 1 stated
staff is only scheduled on 1st and 3rd shifts on weekends
(Saturday and Sunday) and staff typically are scheduled 24/5
during the week. House Supervisor 1 described the shifts as 8-4,
2:30-6:30, 7-11, and 11-7:00. House Supervisor 1 reported the
2

program provides 1 meal per week with life skills coaching and
supervision.
I interviewed Independent Living Worker 1 with State Worker 1
onsite on 2/21/2024. Independent Living Worker 1 described the
participants and program consistent with the information reported
by House Supervisor 1. Independent Living Worker 1 reported
meeting at least weekly with program participants at the
residence.
I interviewed Youth A onsite with State Worker 1 on 2/21/2024.
Youth A described things as going well and reported getting along
with Youth B. Youth A stated sometimes he argues with Youth B,
but staff intervene. Youth A denied any physical confrontations
with Youth B, only verbal. Youth A described finding a
needle/syringe that a youth had used for medication but gave it to
the staff for disposal. Youth A stated participants are able to
contact staff as needed if staff is not present.
State Worker 1 interviewed Youth B separately and Youth B
denied any physical confrontations with Youth A, only verbal
arguments.
Tour:
During a walkthrough of the residence a bathtub was observed
that had a miscellaneous amount of discarded materials and no
needle/syringe was present. Although the bathtub was not usable
there were two showers available for participants to use. House
Supervisor 1 stated it is the intention to remodel the bathroom and
discard the bathtub and install a larger shower area.
Analysis The findings of this investigation determined the residence is
safe/appropriate for participants in this program. The staffing is
consistent with the program requirements. The residence has
adequate showers and personal care facilities even though the
bathtub is currently not usable. No physical confrontation/conflicts
were reported by Youth A or Youth B. The investigation
completed by State Worker 1 also determined no findings.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Eligibility requirements
Title
3

Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12504
Section (2) All the following must be in the case record before a youth is
Description placed in independent living:
(b) The basis for concluding that a youth exhibits self-care
potential.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Youth A calls Youth B slurs. On 02/18/24, Youth A threatened to
kill Youth B, and Youth A pushed Youth B and tried to fight Youth
B. Youth A often leaves the group home door open, and he often
brings people to the group home. These are against the group
home rules. Youth A smokes marijuana in the home. These
incidents indicate Youth A does not exhibit adequate self-care
potential.
Investigation Interviews:
I interviewed Complainant 1 by telephone on 2/20/2024.
Complainant 1 reported Youth A threatens Youth B. Complainant
1 also reported Youth A does not participate/cooperate with the
program expectations. Complainant 1 stated Youth A has been
involved in the program since 10/31/2023.
I interviewed House Supervisor 1 onsite with State Worker 1 on
2/21/2024. House Supervisor 1 described Youth A as not
cooperating with the program expectations, but they are
attempting to facilitate potential alternative placements to meet the
needs of Youth A. House Supervisor 1 reported Youth A as not
doing well in the program.
I interviewed Independent Living Worker 1 with State Worker 1
onsite on 2/21/2024. Independent Living Worker 1 described the
participants and program consistent with the information reported
by House Supervisor 1. Independent Living Worker 1 reported
meeting at least weekly with program participants at the
residence.
I interviewed Youth A onsite with State Worker 1 on 2/21/2024.
Youth A described things as going well and reported getting along
with Youth B. Youth A stated sometimes he argues with Youth B,
but staff intervene. Youth A denied any physical confrontations
with Youth B, only verbal. Youth A stated he has smoked
marijuana at the residence, but the staff took it from him. Youth A
stated he feels safe at the residence/in the program. Youth A
stated he has not been going to school. Youth A stated
4

participants are able to contact staff as needed if staff is not
present.
State Worker 1 interviewed Youth B separately and Youth B
denied any physical confrontations with Youth A, only verbal
arguments.
I interviewed Program Manager 1 onsite with State Worker 1 on
2/21/2024. Program Manager 1 stated they are attempting to work
with Youth A to meet his needs even though Youth A has been
resistant in following Youth A's program objectives. Program
Manager 1 stated they are involved in developing an alternative
placement for Youth A to meet the needs of Youth A.
The Program Statement provided indicates the agency requires
an assessment of a youth for potential placement in this program.
The following documents reviewed confirms this assessment was
completed.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Referring Worker Checklist dated 9/14/2023.
• Referral Form dated 9/14/2023.
• Initial Service Plan dated 7/31/2015.
• Parent/Agency Treatment Plan dated 7/6/2023.
• Referring Worker Assessment of Youth dated
9/18/2023.
• Initial Youth Assessment
• Initial Placement Outline dated 10/27/2023.
• Qualified Individual Assessment dated 2/9/2023.
• Caregiver Assessment of Youth
• Independent Living Agreement dated 11/8/2023.
• Independent Living Contract dated 10/10/2023.
All of the above assessments/documents described Youth A as
having adequate self-care potential to have a successful
placement in this program.
Analysis The findings of this investigation determined the agency did follow
their policies and procedures regarding completing an assessment
of Youth A to be appropriately placed in this Independent Living
Program even though Youth A has yet to fulfill this potential. The
investigation completed by State Worker 1 also determined no
findings.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
